Fig. 1 CO conversions without H2 and with H2 for 5% Cu-CeO2 HT and 5% Cu-CeO2 comm. Blue lines stand for O2 selectivity for both catalysts in PROX of CO with feed composition O2:CO:He: = 1:2:97 at GHSV = 15,000 h−1 in absence of H2 and the feed composition was O2:CO:He:H2 = 2:2:36:60 in presence of H2 (for 5% Cu-CeO2 comm), for 5% Cu-CeO2 HT feed composition was O2:CO:He:H2 = 1:2:37:60 at GHSV = 15,000 h-1. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 A) X-ray diffraction patterns of a) synthesized CeO2; b) 5% Cu-CeO2 HT; c) 5% Cu-CeO2 comm catalysts: B) Rietveld refined XRD pattern of 5% Cu-CeO2 HT. RBragg,-6.325, RF-4.974, χ-1.286. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a, b) TEM images of fresh 5% Cu-CeO2 HT and (c, d) TEM images of spent 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst after 120 h reaction. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Cu K-edge EXAFS spectra of a) the fresh and b) the spent 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst after 120 h. K3-weighted Fourier transform (amplitude (solid curve) and imaginary part (dotted curve)). Observed data: thick curves, fitting data: thin curves. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of a) fresh 5 % Cu-CeO2 HT b) fresh 5% Cu-CeO2 comm. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Ce 3d core level NAPXPS spectra of 5% Cu-CeO2 HT. Graphical abstract Preferential oxidation (PROX) of carbon monoxide (CO) in presence of excess hydrogen is a necessity to prevent poisoning of the Pt-anode by CO in PEMFCs (Polymer Electrolyte Membrane Fuel Cell). A highly active catalyst, 5 wt% Cu-CeO2 showed 100 % CO conversion at 65 °C without any undesirable oxidation of H2. The catalyst showed no deactivation even after 100 h on stream, making it viable for practical fuel cell application. Operando EPR in the PROX reaction condition revealed highly dispersed mixed valent cations with oxygen vacancies, responsible for the low-temperature PROX activity. At the active site, both Cu and Ce ions were shown to reversibly change their valence states to facilitate the abstraction of bridging lattice oxygen for CO oxidation to CO2. This surface oxygen mediated CO oxidation was found to be much faster than that of H2 to H2O, which could explain the complete selectivity of oxygen for CO2 formation. Abbreviations PEMFC Polymer Electrolyte Membrane Fuel Cell TEM transmission electron microscopy XRD X-ray diffraction ICP inductively coupled plasma EPR electron paramagnetic resonance Keywords CuOx-CeO2 PROX Interface Oxygen vacancy Synergistic 1 Introduction Substantial effort has been made in recent years to combat the global climatic challenges by exploiting various green alternatives to fossil fuels. Modern society considers hydrogen as a clean fuel due to its high caloric value with water as the only by-product. Fuel cell (FC) technology has become popular due to its significant efficacy, availability, and performance. Compared to conventional technologies, FC uses hydrogen, which generates electricity in an environmentally benign way (electrochemically) [1]. After reforming of natural gas and liquid hydrocarbons is carried out, a water-gas-shift reaction is performed as the most conventional method to generate hydrogen. The product stream contains hydrogen (55–75 %), carbon dioxide (15–20 %), H2O (10–15 %) and a minimum amount of carbon monoxide (0.3–1 %) [2]. CO adsorbs strongly under operating conditions and poisons the Pt-anode of the Polymer Electrolyte Membrane Fuel Cell (PEMFC) [3]. Hence removal of CO is important to protect the Pt-anode, on which hydrogen is oxidized. Therefore, preferential catalytic carbon monoxide oxidation (PROX) in presence of excess hydrogen is the most crucial strategy for purification of H2 to be used in PEMFC [4,5]. Several noble metal catalysts like Pt, Pd, Ru, Au, along with less expensive and abundant catalysts based on Cu were employed for CO-PROX reaction [1,6–14]. Recently, extensive investigations were attempted with CuOx-CeO2 catalysts, and it was found that such a system is suitable for catalytic PROX of CO in a temperature window of 100−140 °C, both due to high O2 selectivity (60–100 %) and high CO conversion (60–100 %) [2–4,15–19]. Several authors also discussed binary systems like Pt-CeO2, CuOx-CeO2 and thoroughly explained their electronic metal support interactions through computational and experimental approaches [20–23]. They also discussed the several applications of CuOx-CeO2, like preferential oxidation of CO, water gas shift reaction (WGSR), N2O decomposition, and CO2 hydrogenation to value-added products [20,21]. It is found that preparation methods have a profound influence on catalytic activities. During the last few decades, several preparation methods like impregnation [24–27], sol-gel [28,29], co-precipitation [29], deposition precipitation [30], solvated metal atom impregnation [31], inert gas condensation [32], hydrothermal method [33], urea-nitrate combustion [34] were reported. Although several synthetic methods of copper-ceria catalysts have been reported so far, yet none of them can be used for practical FC operating conditions. Either most of the catalysts are only active at high temperature (> 120 °C) or the O2 selectivity is inferior (supplementary material, Table S1). A surfactant assisted hydrothermal method has been developed by our group as a synthetic strategy to prepare nanostructured material [35–43,52]. We report here a similar strategy for the preparation of nanostructured Cu-CeO2 catalyst by our own hydrothermal method and found that this catalyst is showing superior catalytic activity at low temperature. Several scientific groups proposed various views about the active catalytic sites of Cu-CeO2 catalyst. Arantxa Davó-Quiñonero et al. suggested that the job of ceria is subordinate while partially oxidized copper particles attempt oxidation of CO and H2, other than their immediate molecular O2 assisted reoxidation [1]. Yu et al. proposed that the multi-shelled hollow assembly boosts the geometric and electronic cooperation between Cu and CeO2 species and enhances the distribution of reduced Cu+ and Ce3+ species on the surface. This synergistic action amplifies the activity of the reaction [16,20]. Several characterization methods such as XPS, DRIFTS, and TPR have been used to identify the reaction mechanism and active sites responsible for PROX of CO in the CuOx-CeO2 system [2,15,43]. For example, Polster et al. postulated that carbon monoxide oxidation is related to Cu+−CO species by utilizing DRIFTS, while hydration of the catalyst surface leads to deactivation [44]. In situ investigations by X-ray absorption spectroscopy revealed that the active sites for this reaction in the CuOx-CeO2 system are associated with interfacial Cu+ species [45]. By combined operando XANES/DRIFTS measurements, Yao et al. demonstrated that dispersed Cu+ species on CuOx/CeO2 catalyst surface are the active sites for carbon monoxide oxidation rather than CuO [46]. The reducibility and surface nature of Cu-CeO2 catalysts is very complex and usually characterized by different copper species, such as divalent Cu-ions in the CeO2 matrix and CuOx clusters [2]. Elias et al. proposed that the catalytic activity of CuO/CeO2 catalysts originated from the stabilized Cu3+ of the material, and not from interfacial sites [5]. For these reasons, different interpretations and views exist about the character of the active species in carbon monoxide-PROX reaction, and the issue is still unsettled. Some of the mechanistic studies were made under conditions quite far away from the real operating conditions of PEMFC. For instance, EPR spectra for CuOx-CeO2 catalysts have been studied in the range from −196 °C to ambient temperature [47–50]. Moreover, Wang et al. proposed that Cu-monomers act as the active species for CO oxidation at a higher temperature, i.e.,170 °C [51]. Hence, operando EPR measurements under the realistic operating condition of PEMFC are necessary to find out the character of active Cu sites and to monitor the interaction of oxygen with Ce and Cu ions during catalysis. In the current work, we present for the first time, a CuOx-CeO2 catalyst which is active for selective oxidation of carbon monoxide in presence of excess H2 at 65 °C and above, without producing any H2O. Remarkably, this catalyst did not show any deactivation, even up to 120 h. So, it is an ideal candidate for practical PEM fuel cell application [52]. We have successfully employed operando EPR, in-situ DRIFTS, in-situ NAPXPS and DFT calculations to recognize active species in this CuOx-CeO2 catalyst under operating conditions of PEMFC [53]. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Cerium chloride heptahydrate (Acros Organics), anhydrous CuCl2, ethanol (Merck, purity > 99.9 %), 30 % ammonium hydroxide (Merck), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) (Sigma Aldrich) and polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) (Sigma Aldrich) were used for catalyst synthesis in as-received form without further purification. In a typical experiment, 0.53 g CuCl2 and 10.30 g CeCl3.7H2O were dissolved in 150 mL H2O by stirring to form a clear pale blue coloured solution. An ammonia solution (30 %) was added dropwise to adjust pH≈8 in the resulting mixture. Then an H2O-EtOH (ethanolic) solution of CTAB (50 % ethanol) was added under vigorous stirring (2000 rpm) for one hour to form a bluish-green gel. Finally, a solution of 0.09 g PVP in 2 mL aqueous ethanol (50 %) was added to the gel under stirring for two hours. The weight ratio in the final gel was Cu:CTAB:PVP:H2O = 0.25:0.2:0.09:150. The resulting mixture was treated hydrothermally in a Teflon-lined autoclave vessel (stainless-steel) at 180 °C for 24 h. Then, the autoclave was brought down to ambient temperature, the solid material was filtered and washed with excess water until complete removal of chloride ions and dried overnight at 100 °C. Finally, the resulting solid was crushed and calcination was performed in air at 550 °C for six hours to get 5 % Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst. For comparison, a catalyst containing 5 wt% Cu supported commercial CeO2 was also prepared by a conventional impregnation method, denoted as 5% Cu-CeO2 comm (for preparation method, see supplementary material). 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder XRD analysis was done by a PROTO X-ray diffractometer fitted with a Lynx eye high-speed strip detector and a Cu Kα radiation source. Diffraction patterns were recorded between 2°-80 ° region at a rate of 0.5 degrees (2θ)/min. The elemental analysis was performed using ICP Atomic Emission Spectrometer (Model: PS 3000 uv, (DRE), Leeman Labs, Inc (USA)). TEM images were taken using a JEOL JEM 2100 microscope, and samples were prepared by mounting an ethanol-dispersed sample on a lacey carbon formvar-coated Cu grid. Thermo Scientific K-Alpha X-ray photoelectron spectrometer exhibited the X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), and binding energies (±0.1 eV) were derived with respect to the position of C 1s peak at 284.6 eV. NAPXPS spectra in the presence of gas components were recorded at a total pressure of 0.1 mbar with a custom-built near ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (NAPXPS) (Prevac, Poland) equipped with a VG Scienta R3000HP analyzer and MX650 monochromator using monochromatic Al-Kα x-rays at 200 W [70]. NAPXPS experiments were carried out with a cone aperture of 1.2 mm fitted to the bottom of the electrostatic lens regime at a distance of 1.5 mm. Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) measurements at the Cu-K edge were carried out in transmission mode at room temperature at the BL9C station of the Photon Factory at the Institute of Materials Structure Science, High Energy Accelerator Research Organization in Japan (KEK-IMSS-PF). The electron storage ring was operated at 2.5 GeV. A Si(111) channel-cut crystal was used as a monochromator. Ionization chambers for incident X-rays (I0) and transmitted X-rays (I) were filled with N2(100 %) and 25 % Ar/N2 gas, respectively. Analysis of the EXAFS data was performed and fitted using Athena and Artemis package based on IFFEFFIT program. Back-scattering amplitude, and phase shift was calculated by FEFF calculation. TPR measurements were performed by a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 Chemisorption Analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), using a 20 mL min−1 flow of 10 % H2/Ar in a fixed-bed U-shaped reactor with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. Before the experiments, samples were pre-treated at 250 °C for 2 h in 10 % H2/90 % Ar, followed by purging with He for 1 h and cooling to 40 °C. For surface area analysis, N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were conducted at −196 °C (Micromeritics ASAP 2020). Specific surface areas were determined by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. Metal dispersion analysis by N2O decomposition technique was carried out with the help of Micromeritics, Auto Chem II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and Quadrupole mass analyzer connected online with the Chemisorption unit. In situ DRIFTS measurements were carried out by using a high-temperature environmental reaction chamber with ZnSe windows installed in a Praying Mantis (Harrick) optical arrangement. The spectra of the adsorbed species were acquired by elimination of the primary spectrum registered after the reduction step. Operando Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) experiments were conducted utilizing an ELEXSYS-500-12/12 X-band cw-spectrometer (Bruker) operating with a microwave power of 6.3 mW, a modulation frequency and amplitude of 100 kHz and modulation amplitude up to 5 G. The experimentations were carried out in a home-made quartz plug-flow reactor coupled with a gas-dosing device equipped with mass flow controllers (Bronkhorst) at the inlet and a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Omnistar, Pfeiffer Vacuum GmbH) at the outlet for online product analysis. The total gas flow was 30 mL/min. The sample (50 mg catalyst particles of 250−350 μm size) was heated to 300 °C under Ar flow with a ramping rate of 3 °C min−1 and then in situ pre-treated at 250 °C for 1 h in reductive (30 %H2/Ar) atmospheres to form pre-reduced catalyst or with O2 (5% O2/He) to form the pre-oxidized catalyst. Subsequently, the temperature was lowered to the reaction temperature (60 °C in Ar), followed by changes to the individual gas flow. EPR spectra were recorded in 5 min intervals. The following feed gases (in mol%) were used O2:CO:He:H2 = 1:2:37:60 for 5% Cu-CeO2 HT and O2:CO:He:H2 = 2:2:36:60 for 5 % Cu-CeO2 comm. The DFT study for PROX of CO over Cu-CeO2 catalyst was performed using the periodic plane-wave DFT method, Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP 5.3.5). Details of the DFT calculation is given in the supplementary material. 2.3 Catalytic tests The evaluation of activity of the fresh nanocomposites for PROX reaction was done in a continuous downflow fixed-bed-reactor at 3000−15000 h−1 GHSV (gas hourly space velocity). Flow of gas, with a composition (in mol%) of O2:CO:He:H2 = 1:2:37:60 was used as the reactant mixture. The catalyst was pre-treated in 30 % H2/He at 300 °C for 60 min before reaction. In a usual catalytic run, the temperature of the catalyst was increased stepwise from ambient temperature to 150 °C at 2 °C min−1 and was halted at each temperature level for 30 min to attain equilibrium. The compositions of the emitted gases were determined with an online gas chromatograph (TRACE-GC 700 series, Thermo Fischer Scientific) equipped with a TCD (thermal conductivity detector) and an Unibeads C column to separate CO, O2, CO2 and water vapour. Assuming that the total volumes of the reaction gas before and after reaction remained almost the same (< 1 vol.% change), the CO conversions were analyzed as per the following equation: C O c o n v e r s i o n % = n C O i n - n C O o u t n C O i n × 100 % where nCOin and nCOout are the GC peak areas of CO before and after the reactor, respectively. O2 selectivity equation is given as O 2 s e l e c t i v i t y % = 0.5 C O i n - 0.5 C O o u t O 2 i n - O 2 o u t × 100 % where COin, O2in and COout, O2out are the GC peak areas of CO and O2 before and after the reaction, respectively [16]. A quartz tube of 6 mm diameter and 12 cm length was used as a reactor. The flow of gas was regulated by a thermal mass flow controller (TMFC). The whole tubing was heated with the help of dimmerstat (continuously variable voltage auto-transformer) and heating tape. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 CO-PROX reactivity of Cu-CeO2 catalysts Catalytic activities of 5% Cu-CeO2 HT and 5% Cu-CeO2 comm are shown in Fig. 1 . In the absence of H2, the 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst shows activity (10 % CO conversion) already at room temperature (RT) and quickly reaches 100 % CO conversion at 45 °C, whereas 5% Cu-CeO2 comm shows about 25 % CO conversion at 45 °C and 100 % CO conversion only at 130 °C while bare CeO2 (not shown here) does not show any CO oxidation activity in this temperature regime [11]. The PROX measurement in the presence of H2 shows a similar onset activity at room temperature (RT) for 5% Cu-CeO2 HT, while 50 % CO conversion is observed at 42 °C. The complete transformation of CO is achieved for 5% Cu-CeO2 HT at 65 °C in the presence of excess H2 with 100 % selectivity. In contrast, 5% Cu-CeO2 comm shows 50 % CO conversion at 90 °C and 100 % conversion at 160 °C. But its O2 selectivity towards CO2 decreases from 60 % to 45 % with the increase of temperature. From this observation, we can say that 5% Cu-CeO2 HT is a superior catalyst for CO-PROX reaction compared to any of the published reports (Table S1) and 5% Cu-CeO2 comm (Fig. 1). We performed the experiment at higher GHSV at 50,000 h−1, and found that the conversion decreased slightly (100 % to 90 %) compared to the GHSV at 15,000 h−1 keeping O2 selectivity to 100 %. A time on stream (Fig. S16) study was performed for 120 h for both catalysts 5% Cu-CeO2 HT (at 65 °C, with feed composition O2:CO:He:H2 = 1:2:37:60 at GHSV = 15,000 h-1) and 5% Cu-CeO2 comm (at 65 °C, with feed composition O2:CO:He:H2 = 2:2:36:60 at GHSV = 15,000 h-1) (Fig. S16). We can see that 5% Cu-CeO2 HT is superior compared to 5% Cu-CeO2 comm as it shows 100 % CO conversion and 100 % O2 selectivity for 120 h, whereas 5% Cu-CeO2 comm shows deactivation with time as its O2 selectivity decreases from 55 % to 44 % and CO conversion decreases from 24 % to 20 % in this period. We also studied the effect of CO2 and H2O (20 %CO2 and 10 %H2O with the feed mixture) addition, which used to act as inhibitors in the PROX reaction (Fig. S17). We observed that in both cases, the conversion, as well as selectivity, decreased slightly. According to the previous report, whereas the CO2 addition directs the carbonatation of CeO2, H2O demonstrates the manifestation of the blockage of Cu-O-Ce sites, which indicates a prominent CO oxidation inhibition [1]. 3.2 Structure and textural properties of Cu-CeO2 catalysts The elemental composition of 5% Cu-CeO2 HT and 5% Cu-CeO2 comm catalysts determined by ICP-AES (SI-S1) is with 4.8 and 5 wt% Cu, respectively, very close to the nominal input values. The XRD patterns of 5% Cu-CeO2 comm and 5% Cu-CeO2 HT are shown in Fig. 2 . The pattern mostly resembles with the fluorite structured CeO2 showing peaks at 2θ values of 28.54 °, 33.07 °, 47.47 °, 56.33 °, 59.07 °, 69.4 °, 76.68 ° and 79.06 °(JCPDS 81−0792). The crystallite size for the hydrothermally prepared catalyst (5% Cu-CeO2 HT) was determined by the Scherrer equation, and it was 11.3 nm, whereas the crystallite size for 5% Cu-CeO2 comm is 24.3 nm. In addition to the CeO2 phase, very weak peaks of CuO (JCPDS card no. 45-0937) were also observed in the case of 5 % Cu-CeO2 comm, but 5% Cu-CeO2 HT shows no copper peaks. The absence of any Cu peaks in the XRD patterns may be due to either poor crystallization, highly dispersed Cu species on CeO2 or the formation of Cu-O-Ce solid solution [34]. HR-TEM analysis (discussed later) showed the presence of Cu-lattice fringes, so the amorphous nature of the Cu species can be ruled out. A small peak shift to higher 2θ angles in 5% Cu-CeO2 HT compare to 5% Cu-CeO2 comm was observed (shown in Fig. 2A). If the size of the doping element (Cu) is smaller than its substituting element (Ce), then the lattice parameter will decrease as compared to the pure CeO2 (Vegard's law). Actually, Cu2+ substitution in the CeO2 matrix is confirmed by a decrease in the lattice parameter from 5.4247 Å for pure CeO2 to 5.4077 Å for 5% Cu-CeO2 HT [15]. So, XRD analysis shows Cu2+ ions are incorporated into the CeO2 lattice and the possibility of forming Cu-O-Ce solid solution [34]. Lattice parameter values of synthesized CeO2, 5% Cu-CeO2 HT and 5% Cu-CeO2 comm have been estimated using PROZSKI program. The obtained respective lattice parameters are 5.4247, 5.4077 and 5.4481 Å. It is to be noted that the ionic radius of Cu2+ is 0.87 Å, whereas that for Ce4+ is 1.01 Å [54]. In this sense, lattice parameters would decrease in Cu-CeO2 catalysts with respect to pure CeO2 if the Ce4+ site is substituted by Cu2+ as the ionic radius of Cu2+ is smaller than that of Ce4+ (Vegard's law). Indeed, in the present study, there is a decrease in the lattice parameters in 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst in comparison with pure CeO2, indicating the substitution of Cu2+ ions into Ce4+ sites (Fig. 2B). The lattice parameter value for prepared CeO2 is 5.4247 Å. It was observed that in case of impregnated catalyst (5% Cu-CeO2 comm) the lattice parameter increases from 5.4247 to 5.4481 Å. This is because Ce4+ (ionic radius 1.01 Å) is reduced to Ce3+ (ionic radius 1.15 Å). This is also confirmed from the XRD spectra as the 2θ value decreased from 28.52 to 28.40, so lattice expansion was taken place. But in case of prepared catalyst (5% Cu-CeO2 HT) Ce4+ (ionic radius 1.01 Å) was replaced by Cu2+ (ionic radius 0.87 Å) and the contraction of the lattice parameter was observed from 5.4247 to 5.4077 Å and this is confirmed from the XRD spectra as the 2θ value increased from 28.52 to 28.64, so lattice contraction was taken place. Copper being in the lower oxidation states (Cu+ (0.91 Å) and Cu2+ (0.87 Å)), it is inevitable to get associated with oxygen vacancies, which in turn requires Ce3+ (Ce3+ (1.15 Å) and (Ce4+ (1.01 Å)) to be adjacent, to recompense oxygen vacancy as well as structural stress due to smaller size of Cu-ions. S. T. Hossain et al. also found a similar type of findings [34]. This observation agrees well with the findings in the literature for this type of catalyst. Bera and co-workers have substituted 5 at.% Cu into CeO2 lattice using solution combustion synthesis [15]. Chen and co-workers also observed the same type of findings [17]. Gamarra et al. have substituted upto 20 at.% Cu into CeO2 lattice by reverse microemulsion method wherein a systematic decrease in lattice parameters of Cu substituted CeO2 catalysts is observed [4]. As the scattering factor between cerium and oxygen differs significantly, the absolute value of the oxygen occupancy is not reliable. (Exact oxygen content would be evaluated from neutron diffraction data.) However, in the present work, a systematic decrease in the lattice parameters in the 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst would indicate the substitution of Cu into CeO2 lattice. The BET surface area of the fresh and spent 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst are 58 and 56 m2/g, respectively, whereas that of 5% Cu-CeO2 comm is only 12 m2/g. TEM images of the fresh and spent 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . The fresh 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst exhibits CeO2 particles in the size dimensions of 4−10 nm. Fig. S1 represents HRTEM images of the fresh and used 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst in which inter-planar d-spacings of 0.32 nm correspond to the CeO2 {111} facets [55]. At very few positions in the TEM images, there was some indication of lattice planes with a distance of 0.23 nm that could point to CuO {111} facets. However, these features were hard to find. This confirms the high dispersion of CuOx species in 5% Cu-CeO2 HT and explains why no CuO features were detected in the XRD powder patterns of this catalyst. In fact, the Cu dispersion analysis by the N2O decomposition method (SI-S1) over 5 % Cu-CeO2 HT was 37 %, which is very high compared to the dispersion value of only 12 % for 5% Cu-CeO2 comm catalyst. Furthermore, the STEM mapping analysis (Fig. S3 a–d) validates that the distribution of both Ce and Cu ions in 5% Cu-CeO2 HT is homogeneous. TEM analysis also showed that the particle size of the fresh catalyst (≈3 to 6 nm) does not change much during use and remains at ≈3–12 nm (Fig. 3 and S1), suggesting that their textural properties are almost retained. In the case of commercial catalyst, TEM analysis (see supplementary information Fig. S2) exhibited that the particle size of the fresh catalyst displayed a broad distribution in the range between 10−20 nm, while in spent catalyst, the commercial catalyst showed mostly the formation of agglomerated particles. Both the catalysts (HT catalyst and commercial catalyst) were polycrystalline before and after the reaction. The Fourier transform Cu K-edge EXAFS spectra of the fresh and spent 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 , and the curve fittings results are summarized in Table S2. For the shell of the fresh catalyst, Cu-O distance was 1.946 ± 0.014 Å, and the Cu-O co-ordination number (CN) was 3.4 ± 0.6. These Cu-species are stable during catalysis. The structural parameters were determined by the Cu K-edge EXAFS for 5% Cu-CeO2HT after 120 h PROX reaction, indicating no significant change of the Cu-species. The Cu-O co-ordination number in the spent catalyst was 3.4 ± 0.6, and the Cu-O distance was 1.936 ± 0.013 Å. The XAFS analysis indicates that the Cu-species are very stable and not changing the structure during catalysis. Fig. 5 displays H2-TPR profiles of fresh 5% Cu-CeO2 HT and 5% Cu-CeO2 comm catalysts, where the spectra have four types of peaks (α, β, γ, δ). In contrast to the catalysts in Fig. 5, it is reported in the literature that pure CeO2 shows two peaks at a much higher temperature, around 500 °C and 850 °C [56,57]. This indicates that the integration of CuOx in CeO2 increases reducibility markedly, which is very important since the PROX reaction occurs below 100 °C [10]. Peak α at low temperature is observed as the highly dispersed CuOx species actively interacting with CeO2 is reduced, while the area of peak β is always larger than that of α. XRD results show that part of the Cu2+ ions replace Ce4+ to form a CuxCe1-xO2- δ solid-state solution. Therefore, peak α is formed by the reduction of the highly dispersed CuOx species, and peak β is formed due to the reduction of Cu2+ ions in CuxCe1-xO2-δ [58]. The formation of such a solid solution is especially pronounced in the 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst, evidenced by the decrease of the lattice parameter as revealed by XRD [59]. The high-temperature peaks, γ and δ are related to the reduction of bulk CuO [58]. Since they are only found in the less active 5% Cu-CeO2 comm catalyst, it can be concluded that bulk copper species show poor PROX performance. In contrast, species α and β, which reflect highly dispersed CuOx species dominating in the HT catalyst, might be responsible for its higher performance. This suggests that the interaction between highly dispersed CuOx and ceria support is the primary factor behind the generation of easily reducible surface capping oxygen of the cerium oxide (see Table S4). Theoretically, H2 consumption values based on Cu2+ present on the catalyst are 0.75 mmol/g and 0.78 mmol/g, respectively, for 5% Cu-CeO2 HT and 5% Cu-CeO2 comm. The experimental H2 consumption values are 0.89 mmol/g and 0.81 mmol/g, respectively, for 5% Cu-CeO2 HT and 5% Cu-CeO2 comm. So, the experimental H2 uptake value is higher than the theoretical value. The TPR study explains that Cu2+ ion in the 5% Cu-CeO2 HT can be reduced at a lower temperature than that for reduction of Cu2+ in 5% Cu-CeO2 comm. Additionally, as the Cu2+ ion is reduced completely to metallic Cu (Cu0), some of the Ce4+ ions seem to get reduced at lower temperature. The H2-TPR analysis suggests that Cu2+ ion is incorporated in the CeO2 matrix, and an interaction between Cu2+ ion and CeO2 brings down the reduction temperature of Cu2+ ion and Ce4+ ion partially. Hence, the experimental H2 consumption value is higher than the theoretical H2 consumption value [15]. 3.3 XPS NAPXPS studies were carried out in the presence of reactants at a total pressure of 0.1 mbar to evaluate for changes in dispersion and oxidation states of the 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst surfaces under controlled conditions, e.g., during oxidation or reduction, as well as with various feed components [1,18]. The results are shown in Fig. 6–8 for O 1s, Ce 3d, and Cu 2p3/2 core levels, respectively. The Ce 3d core level spectra for fresh 5% Cu-CeO2 HT have been deconvoluted into two groups of signals for the Ce 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 region, marked with u and v, respectively (Fig. 6) [60,61]. Sub-signals v‴, v″, v and as well as u‴, u″, u and corresponds to Ce4+ while peaks u°, u',v° and v', arise from the respective transitions of Ce3+ [62]. Sub-signals represent various configuration interaction due to charge transfer between different Ce oxidation states with oxide anions. Inspection of the spectrum (a) in Fig. 6A and B readily reveals that Ce is present in both valence states +3 and +4. Upon oxidation at 280 °C in O2 at 0.1 mbar, no significant change of the XPS spectrum is evident (b in Fig. 6A). However, treatment at 280 °C in 0.1 mbar H2, results in a slight reduction of the v″ signal (b in Fig. 6B), indicating a partial reduction of Ce4+, which is also supported by a concomitant increase of the v° and other subpeaks of Ce3+ [1]. Introduction of 0.1 mbar CO at 60 °C to either the pre-oxidized (c in Fig. 6A) or the pre-reduced 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst (c in Fig. 6B) does not show significant changes. This indicates that even the pre-reduced surface provides readily available surface oxygen for CO2 formation. Indeed, CO2 formation was observed upon dosing CO over the pre-reduced HT catalyst (Fig. S4 in SI). Upon subsequent dosing of CO + O2 (d in Fig. 6B), the spectrum does not change compared to CO treatment only. Nevertheless, the v″ subpeak shows an increase in intensity (Fig. 6A-d), indicating a possible filling of oxygen vacancies and hence oxidation to Ce4+. Interestingly, upon dosing of CO:O2:H2 (2:1:3) at 60 °C, similar spectra were recorded in both panels of Fig. 6, v' and v″ show comparable intensity under these conditions. Although the pressure employed in the catalytic activity measurements is much higher (1 bar), the changes observed in the XPS spectra reflect the behaviour of sample 5% Cu-CeO2 HT in the catalytic activity measurements. Cu 2p3/2 peaks are displayed in Fig. 7, under the same conditions as indicated in the caption of Fig. 6. The simultaneous presence of Cu+ and Cu2+ oxidation states is reflected by peaks at 932.4 (blue line) and 933.8 eV (red line), respectively (Fig. 8A-a and 8B-a) [18]. In addition, a small amount of Cu(OH)2 (green trace at 934.8 eV) was also observed, which is present even under reaction conditions. Moreover, a peak at 930.0 eV was observed (pink line in Fig. 7). The origin of this signal is not clear. Although two earlier reports attribute a feature at 930 eV to Cu+, we cannot assign this line accordingly since the corresponding Cu 2p1/2 feature was not observed (result not shown) [63,64]. Upon O2 treatment at 0.1 mbar and 280 °C (Fig. 7A-b), no significant change occurs, while the Cu+ component increases significantly on treatment with hydrogen at the same temperature (Fig. 7B-b). Upon CO introduction, a marginal increase in Cu+ content was observed (Fig. 7A-c), due to oxidation of CO to CO2 by lattice oxygen in the vicinity of Cu2+, leading to a reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ [65]. Similar Cu 2p peaks were observed on dosing CO + O2 and CO + O2+H2 at 60 °C (in Fig. 7A and B), indicating the maintenance of Cu+ as well as Cu2+ species under dynamic reaction conditions [66]. This indicates that the presence of H2 hardly changes the valence state distribution of the surface copper species in time average, pointing to a fast redox cycle and the robust nature of the catalyst. Observation of mixed valent copper as well as cerium surface species, the ratio of which remains more or less constant in time average under both CO + O2 as well as CO + O2+H2 conditions, suggests synergistic effects in utilizing the oxygen at the interface of CuOx-Ceria for CO oxidation and refilling the resulting vacancies with gas-phase oxygen. Table 1 shows the percentage changes in the various oxidation states of Ce and Cu. For Ce(III) content calculations, the areas under the sub-peaks of all Ce(III) features are added. Similarly for Ce(IV) was calculated. It is to be noted that Ce(IV) (Ce(III)) content changes marginally between 84 and 77 % (16 and 24 %), irrespective of any treatment. Similarly, Cu (II) (Cu(I)) percentage content also changes in a narrow range of 75 and 87 % (13 and 25 %). It is also to be highlighted that the latter two conditions (CO + O2 and CO + O2+H2) in both tables show very small variation in oxidation states of Ce and Cu, demonstrating the catalyst surface is really robust. It is to be underscored that these are the measurements under actual operating conditions of PROX, except for pressure at 0.1 mbar. O 1s core level spectra, recorded under the same conditions as in Figs. 6 and 7, show three peaks from lattice oxide ions (529.5 eV, red), surface oxygen bound to defect sites (530.6 eV, blue), and OH species (532.0 eV, pink) (Fig. 8) [67,68]. An additional shoulder was observed at 528.5 eV on the fresh catalyst in UHV (green), which decreases markedly in the presence of gas components. This O species should be the most electron-rich (O(2+x)−) than the lattice oxygen, which is typical O2-. Therefore, the possibility of finding the electron-rich oxygen in the vicinity of reduced metal ions such as Cu+ and/or Ce3+, [14]. Copper being in the lower oxidation states (Cu+ (0.91 Å) and Cu2+ (0.87 Å)), it is inevitable to get associated with oxygen vacancies, which in turn necessitates Ce3+ (Ce3+ (1.15 Å) and (Ce4+ (1.01 Å)) to be nearby, to compensate oxygen vacancy as well as structural stress due to smaller size of Cu-ions.This type of oxygen species is also expected to promote the redox cycle, which is an essential requirement for the PROX reaction. The mixed valent cations and oxygen vacancies can be connected in many possible ways; however, as we have no direct proof for any particular structural unit, we do not want to speculate. This signal decreased strongly upon exposure of the catalyst 5% Cu-CeO2 HT to O2 (Fig. 8A-b), probably due to oxidation of the neighbouring reduced metal ions, while it disappeared entirely in H2 (Fig. 8B-b), possibly since it oxidizes the latter to H2O. Moreover, the signals of defect sites (530.6 eV) and OH species (532.0 eV) decrease strongly while that of lattice oxygen remains constant. Subsequent exposure to CO only (spectra c) does not cause any changes, but under total PROX feed in the presence of oxygen, the above discussed special surface O species reappeared. This suggests that it is not the lattice oxide ions (529.5 eV) but these special surface oxygen species that react with CO and are replenished by gas-phase O2. Indeed, the green trace at 528.5 eV was not observed for CO + O2 (Fig. 8B, trace d), and we don't know the reason for the same. 3.4 In-situ DRIFTS study To identify the key intermediates on the surface of 5% Cu-CeO2 HT under technically relevant conditions, in-situ DRIFTS studies were performed between 20 °C and 80 °C with 2:1 ratio of CO:O2. Three distinct spectral regions were observed. Between 1000 and 1700 cm−1, bands due to carbonate and associated species appeared [69]. Bi-dentate carbonates showing bands at ca. 1565 and 1280 cm-1 are the most intense features in this spectral region (Fig. S5 (a). This is possible due to the evolution of CO2 and its adsorption on the catalyst surface. The bands at 2110 cm−1 are due to Cu+−CO species, which are in agreement with the presence of Cu+ also detected by NAPXPS (Fig. 7) [69,70]. The formation of Cu+−CO species is associated with the reduction of Cu2+ promoted by the support (also evidenced by XPS, Fig. 7). In general, the intensity of the carbonyl species depends on the available surface-exposed Cu+ centres, CO concentration, as well as temperature [46]. The existence of CeO2 promotes the formation of surface interfacial Cu+ sites, and it also stabilizes the active Cu+ site in 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst. Such Ce4+/Ce3+-induced stabilization of surface Cu+ entities is crucial to stop their further reduction to Cu° and create the surface-active sites for hydrogen oxidation and water formation [71]. Bands at 2360 and 2337 cm-1 show the production of gaseous CO2, indicating the oxidation of CO (Fig. 9 a). The region of Cu+−CO species is shown in more detail in Fig. 9b [3]. The 2080−2140 cm-1 and 2000−2115 cm-1 regions are responsible for Cu+−CO species and Cu°−CO species, respectively [19]. So, bands at 2078 cm-1 are assigned to Cu°−CO and, 2099, 2108 and 2124 cm-1 are assigned to Cu+−CO. Over 5% Cu-CeO2 HT, we observed an intense band at 2108 cm−1, assigned to CO adsorbed on interfacial copper ions connected via oxygen to adjacent cerium ion [19,59]. It is expected that this strengthens the interaction with the ceria support [19,59]. The band corresponding to 2108 cm−1 is associated with CO bound to Cu+ species on the surface of the Ce1-xCuxO2 solid solution, as this is the main component of the HT catalyst [59]. In addition, there are two bands red-shifted from the one at 2108 cm−1 (2078 and 2099 cm−1), indicating an intense interaction of the Cu+ with the basic CeO2 support as well [3]. It was accounted for that the more intense CuC bond reflected the red shift of the Cu+−CO band to the lower band frequency because the electron moves from the d electrons of the Cu+ to the CO triggered by the intense CuCe interface [19]. It is observed that as the temperature increased, the intensity of Cu°-CO species decreased and the intensity of CO2 increased. 3.5 Operando EPR study Operando EPR investigations of the 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst coupled with mass spectrometry (MS) were performed at 60 °C [72–76]. The EPR spectrum of the oxidized catalyst (treated at 250 °C in O2 for 2 h) shows an axial signal at g|| = 2.306 and g⊥ = 2.071 of Cu2+ ions with hyperfine structure (hfs) A|| = 116 and A⊥ = 26 G (Fig. 10 ) produced by the magnetic interaction between the spin of the unpaired electron with nuclear spin of Cu (I = 3/2) and reflects Cu2+ sites in tetragonally distorted environment since g|| > g⊥ > ge [76,77]. Upon exposure of the pre-oxidized catalyst, 5% Cu-CeO2 HT to flowing CO at 60 °C, a decrease of the Cu2+ signal was observed along with a sudden increase of the signal at g⊥ = 1.962 and g|| = 1.94 (very weak). Its assignment is not without controversy in the literature. It has been ascribed to Ce3+ ions [74]. However, it is also known that, due to strong spin-orbit coupling, Ce3+ ions are usually detectable only at very low temperatures [48,78]. Therefore, this signal has been occasionally assigned to Cr3+ impurities in the CeO2 lattice rather than to Ce3+ [77]. However, we attribute this line to Ce3+ ions on the surface associated with a defect centre (e. g. an oxygen vacancy, Ce3+-□), since it gains intensity under reductive conditions in the presence of CO and/ or H2, which might not be the case for a Cr3+ centre (Fig. 10 and 11 ) [75]. The sudden rise of the EPR signal at g⊥ = 1.962 right after switching to CO (Fig. 10) shows clearly that CO can be oxidized by surface oxygen from a Cu2+-O-Ce4+ moiety to form CO2 (evident from online MS, Fig. S6), thus creating oxygen vacancies in the vicinity of Cu+ and Ce3+ (Ce3+-□-Cu+). Strikingly, this EPR signal decreases again with time, probably due to increasing concentration of Ce3+ ions, which favours magnetic interaction between them. No significant changes of the EPR spectrum were observed after switching from CO to O2 flow at 60 °C, suggesting that oxidation of Cu+ to Cu2+ by molecular O2 is slow. This suggests that O2 from the gas phase is merely activated by Ce3+ ions during the catalytic reaction. When H2 was fed to the pre-oxidized 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst, the EPR signal of Ce3+-□ at g⊥ = 1.962 increased as well but reached its maximum only after 1 h (Fig. 11). The signal intensity after 55 min under H2 is comparable to that obtained after the immediate introduction of CO only (compare inset of Figs. 10 and 11). This indicates that oxidation reaction of CO with a Cu2+-O-Ce4+ surface moiety is much faster than oxidation of H2 on the same site and might explain the high selectivity of the PROX reaction on this catalyst by surface oxygen. Fascinatingly, the EPR signal of Cu2+ single sites increased slightly with time despite the presence of H2 acting as a reducing agent (Fig. 11). A possible explanation may be that H2 reacts preferentially with Cu2+ ions in EPR-silent antiferromagnetic CuOx clusters [79]. The formation of such species is suggested by a comparison of the EPR intensity of 5% Cu-CeO2 HT measured at 293 K (20 °C) and 100 K (−173 °C). The intensity ratio, I100/I293 = 2.63 (double integral) is slightly lower than that expected for the exclusive presence of paramagnetic species (I100/I293 = 2.93). Partial reduction of Cu2+ by H2 would form diamagnetic Cu+ ions, which disturb antiferromagnetic interaction between neighbouring Cu2+, thus making the latter EPR-active [73,80,81]. Upon exposure of the 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst to the total PROX feed (CO/H2/O2 in Ar), similar behaviour of the Ce3+-□ signal as under CO only is observed (compare Figs. 10 and S8), yet a temporal decrease of the Cu2+ signal is hardly seen in Fig. S8. This might be due to fast reoxidation of Cu+ (formed by CO oxidation) to Cu2+, which keeps the latter signal unchanged in time average. Excitingly, monitoring of the product formation by MS (Fig. S6) showed the formation of CO2 but not of H2O, confirming the high selectivity of PROX over this catalyst. The spectral behaviour indicates that both Cu and Ce work cooperatively during the PROX reaction (Eqs. 1 and 2). (1) Cu2+-O-Ce4++ CO → Ce3+-□-Cu+ + CO2 (2) Ce 3+-□-Cu+ + ½ O2 → Cu2+-O-Ce4+ The decrease of the total Cu2+ intensity in the presence of only reducing gases (CO or H2 without O2) during the experiments in Figs. 10 and 11 is only about 3%. This means that only a small part of the total Cu2+ sites in the catalyst participates in the reaction. Most probably, these are Cu2+ species directly exposed on the surface, while those incorporated in the CeO2 lattice (forming the solid solution) might be inactive. For the same reason, it was quite tricky to detect the formation of Cu+ by bulk techniques, e.g., XRD or XANES. However, the surface analysis of the catalyst by XPS supports this finding, which showed that there is an increase in the atomic percentage of Cu+ from 13.1 to 18.2% (in case of O2 pretreatment, Table 1(a)) and 24.9–25.4% (in case of H2 pretreatment, Table 1(b)) upon reaction with CO. In contrast to catalyst 5% Cu-CeO2 HT, the EPR spectrum of the commercial sample 5% Cu-CeO2 comm after pre-oxidation in O2 at 280 °C shows a signal of Cu2+ species, which are located preferentially within larger CuOx agglomerates, since no hfs structure is resolved (Fig. S11). This is also supported by the ratio of the EPR signal intensity (double integral) of these Cu2+ species, I100/I293 = 1.63 measured at 293 K (20 °C) and 100 K (-173 °C) (Fig. S7), which is much smaller than the value of I100/I293 = 2.93 expected for pure paramagnetic species based on the linear relationship between temperature and EPR intensity. As mentioned above, in the hydrothermally prepared highly active catalyst 5% Cu-CeO2 HT, this intensity ratio is close to that expected for pure paramagnetic behaviour (I100/I293 = 2.63), indicating a much higher dispersion of Cu2+ in agreement with the outcomes obtained from XRD and TEM. In agreement with the low catalytic activity of 5% Cu-CeO2 comm (Fig. 1), almost no changes of the corresponding EPR spectra were observed upon the addition of different feeds (Figs. S9−11). Consequently, the larger CuOx clusters reflected in this sample by the broad EPR signal without hfs might be inactive for the PROX reaction. It should be noted that the EPR signal intensity of Ce3+ ions associated with an oxygen vacancy increased when both the catalysts were subjected to CO only (compare Figs. 10 and S9). However, H2 oxidation to H2O is less pronounced with the present catalyst and much faster by Cu cluster over the commercial catalyst (compare Figs. 11 and S10). It seems to be that H2O blocked the active site responsible for CO oxidation at reaction temperature (less than 100 °C). This could explain the reason for the different selectivity. 3.6 DFT results DFT optimized geometry of CeO2(111) is shown in Fig. S12(a). Due to the lattice disruption caused by the Cu dopant, the surface oxygen (O(1), O(2) and O(3)) becomes highly active, forming the Cu-O-Ce active site for the PROX reaction, which is also supported by XRD, XPS, EPR, XAFS analysis. The reactive surface oxygen atom O1 reacts with the CO molecule forming CO2, as shown in Fig. S13. The reaction is highly exothermic with the reaction energy calculated to be -365.9 kJ/mol. The activation barrier for the formation of the second CO2 molecule is calculated to be 104.1 kJ/mol. In the transition state (Fig. S14(a')), the Cu—O(2) and Cu-C bond gets elongated to 2.16 Å and 1.9 Å, respectively, whereas the C- O(2) bond gets shortened to 2.51 Å. In the product state, the CO2 molecule gets formed with the O(2) is completely dissociated from the surface (Fig. S14(b)). Desorption of the second CO2 molecule creates two oxygen vacancies at the Cu-CeO2 active site, as observed in Fig. S15(a). O2(g) molecule adsorption at the oxygen vacancy site (Ov(1)), as shown in Fig. S15(b), is exothermic by 268.9 kJ/mol. The O2 molecule adsorbed at the Ov(1) dissociates over the Cu-O-Ce active site to fill both the surface oxygen vacancy Ov(1) and Ov(2), as shown in Fig. S15(b). The dissociation of the O2 molecule and adsorption of the O atoms at the two O-vacancy regenerate the Cu-CeO2(111) surface for the next catalytic cycle. The activation energy for the O2 dissociation is calculated as 136 kJ/mol, and the reaction energy is found out to be endothermic by 20.6 kJ/mol. A reaction free energy diagram (HTS) for the CO oxidation catalytic cycle over the Cu-CeO2(111) surface at 50 °C temperature is shown in Fig. 12 . The adsorbed CO abstracts a surface oxygen to form the second CO2 molecule. The activation free energy barrier for the second CO2 molecule formation is calculated to be 104 kJ/mol, whereas the reaction free energy is found out endergonic by 25.3 kJ/mol, as shown in Fig. 12. The desorption of the second CO2 creates two oxygen vacancy sites as the Cu-CeO2 surface. Gas-phase O2 molecule gets strongly adsorbed at one of the oxygen vacancy sites with the reaction free energy calculated to be −410 kJ/mol (Fig. 12). The activation free energy barrier for the dissociation of the adsorbed O2 is calculated to be 136 kJ/mol, whereas the reaction free energy is found out endergonic by 20.6 kJ/mol, as shown in Fig. 12. The overall reaction is thermodynamically favourable as can be seen from the highly negative reaction free energy (−576.4 kJ/mol, Fig. 12). 3.7 Structure-reactivity relationships A comparison of the two catalysts, 5 % Cu-CeO2 HT and 5% Cu-CeO2 comm shows that catalytic activity is strongly correlated with high Cu dispersion. This is preferentially realized that hydrothermally prepared catalyst contains Ce-O-Cu moieties where one Cu2+ replaces a Ce4+ ion in the CeO2, and the CeO2 lattice parameter decreased from 5.4481 Å to 5.4077 Å as the smaller Cu ions were incorporated in the ceria matrix, preferentially for the highly active HT catalyst [15,17,34,54]. In contrast, catalyst 5% Cu-CeO2 comm contains larger CuO crystallites, even detectable by XRD. H2-TPR (Fig. 5) revealed that both the highly dispersed CuO clusters and incorporated single Cu2+ ions in CeO2 lattice (found in HT catalyst) are much more reducible and, thus, much more active than Cu2+ in larger CuO particles (present in the commercial catalyst). NAPXPS (Fig. 7A-c) and operando EPR studies (Figs. 10 and 11) together also confirmed the presence of mixed valent cations and oxygen vacancies, and it is likely that Cu and Ce ions work cooperatively during the PROX reaction and change their valence states reversibly (Eqs. 1 and 2, Fig. 12). Intriguingly, in situ EPR suggested much faster oxidation of CO than of H2 on Cu2+-O-Ce4+ surface moieties (Figs. 10 and 11), while oxidation of H2 to H2O might be catalyzed mainly by larger antiferromagnetic CuO clusters. Since the latter plays a minor role in the HT catalysts, this may be one reason for its high selectivity. The hydrothermal synthesis of nano-sized CeO2 with high surface area and abundant anchoring positions for Cu ions to form Cu-O-Ce heterojunctions promotes oxygen vacancies and facilitates formation of redox-active Cu+/Cu2+ and Ce3+/Ce4+ surface species under reaction conditions. This enhances the formation of Cu+-carbonyl species by adsorption of CO (confirmed by DRIFTS experiments), whereby the formation of Cu+ is supported by powerful highly-dispersed Cux+-CeO2 interaction [19,44–65]. 4 Conclusions We developed a new protocol for the hydrothermal synthesis of a nanocrystalline CuOx-CeO2 catalyst, and it showed 100 % conversion of CO at 65 °C and 100 % selectivity of O2 towards CO in presence of excess hydrogen, without the latter getting partially burnt. As far as we know, the 5% Cu-CeO2 HT exhibited superior catalytic performance in the PROX reaction, which has not been reached before, which makes this catalyst a suitable candidate for practical PEM fuel cell applications. Moreover, 5% Cu-CeO2 HT catalyst is essentially stable under PROX conditions, showing no deactivation in a long-term test for more than 100 h because of the selectivity of O2 towards CO in presence of excess hydrogen. The catalyst showed a uniform Cu dispersion (≈37 %), detected by N2O decomposition. The highly dispersed Cu species in the HT catalyst are much more reducible than those in the Cu-CeO2 comm reference catalyst (detected by H2-TPR), which may account for its higher activity. These bridging -O- ions oxidize the CO much faster than H2 under PROX conditions (evidenced by in situ EPR), while undesirable H2 oxidation might be driven mainly by larger antiferromagnetic CuO particles (hardly present in Cu-CeOHT but abundant in Cu-CeO2 comm). The effective incorporation of Cu to CeO2 within abundant Cu-O-Ce heterojunctions in the HT catalyst is supposed to facilitate the formation of Cu+ by electron transfer from Ce4+ to Cu2+ (detected by in situ EPR). This might promote the formation of Cu+ carbonyl species (confirmed by DRIFTS). coredata.dc:description: Preferential oxidation (PROX) of carbon monoxide (CO) in presence of excess hydrogen is a necessity to prevent poisoning of the Pt-anode by CO in PEMFCs (Polymer Electrolyte Membrane Fuel Cell). A highly active catalyst, 5 wt% Cu-CeO2 showed 100 % CO conversion at 65 °C without any undesirable oxidation of H2. The catalyst showed no deactivation even after 100 h on stream, making it viable for practical fuel cell application. Operando EPR in the PROX reaction condition revealed highly dispersed mixed valent cations with oxygen vacancies, responsible for the low-temperature PROX activity. At the active site, both Cu and Ce ions were shown to reversibly change their valence states to facilitate the abstraction of bridging lattice oxygen for CO oxidation to CO2. This surface oxygen mediated CO oxidation was found to be much faster than that of H2 to H2O, which could explain the complete selectivity of oxygen for CO2 formation.
coredata.dc:title: In-situ experimental and computational approach to investigate the nature of active site in low-temperature CO-PROX over CuOx-CeO2 catalyst
